In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Over the last 5 years, the Islamic Financial Services Board (IFSB), as an international 
standard-setting organization, has developed a range of standards and guidance papers to 
promote and enhance the soundness and stability of the Islamic financial services industry, 
broadly  defined  to  include  banking,  capital  markets,  and  insurance  sectors.  The  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB), in recognition of the growing significance of Islamic finance among 
its developing member countries, joined the IFSB as an observer in 2003 and became an 
associate member in 2006. ADB’s regional technical assistance (TA) for the Development of 
International Prudential Standards for Islamic Financial Services,1 which was cofinanced by Islamic 
Development  Bank  (IDB),  provided  support  to  the  IFSB.  Specifically,  ADB  and  IFSB 
collaborated to develop a set of international prudential standards for the supervision of Islamic 
financial services. Building upon this partnership and accomplishments of the aforementioned 
TA, it is proposed to continue ADB support for Islamic financing. The focus is to be on further 
enhancing prudential and supervision standards, as well as on various measures needed for 
effective implementation.2 This undertaking would deepen the broader partnership with IDB, 
including to develop an institutional infrastructure for a more effective use of Islamic finance 
among the common member countries.3 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Since the mid-1970s, when there were few Islamic banks, Islamic finance has grown 
rapidly (at an estimated average annual rate of 10% to 15%) both globally and in the region. As 
a result, there is now a proliferation of Islamic institutions and a trend toward mainstreaming 
with  interest-based  conventional  finance.  There  are  currently  approximately  400  Islamic 
financial institutions throughout 53 countries,4 some of which are global players and offer an 
extensive range of Shari’ah (Islamic law) compliant products (money, debt, and capital market) 
and services to a broad spectrum of consumers and businesses. There is also an increasing 
demand  for  diversifying  Shari’ah-compliant  financial  products  and  services.  While  Islamic 
finance has historically concentrated on commercial banking, potential areas for future growth 
today include investment banking, asset management, capital markets, and private banking. 
With approximately 1.5 billion Muslims in the world, and increasing interest among non-Muslims 
for alternative financing modes and investments, the potential for growth of Islamic financial 
markets  worldwide  is  vast.  Current  global  Islamic  banking  assets  and  assets  under 
management have reached $750 billion and is expected to exceed $1 trillion by 2010.5 That 
would be about five times what they were in 2002. The year 2007, in particular, saw exceptional 
growth in the global sukuk (Islamic securities) market, which expanded by more than 70% 
during the year. New issues in 2007 reached a record high of about $47 billion, and the 
outstanding global sukuk market has now surpassed the $100 billion mark.6

3.  In Southeast Asia, there is a growing demand for Islamic finance products and markets 
in Brunei Darussalam, Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore, and Thailand. Malaysia has long played 
a leading role in developing Islamic finance and often acts as a benchmark for many in the 
region. In particular, Malaysia is the world’s largest sukuk issuance center, with over $25 billion, 
or 53%, of the world’s sukuk issues in 2007. According to an Islamic Finance Information 
Service report, Southeast Asia (and specifically Malaysia) continues to offer the most accessible 
markets for small and medium-sized borrowers. Fifty-five of the sukuk issued in Southeast Asia 
during 2007 have each been worth between $1 million and $10 million, whereas not a single 
sukuk in other regions has fallen within that range.7 Indonesia has also made several notable 
improvements in its regulatory and legal provisions. Among them, it passed a new Islamic 
banking law in May 2008 that will allow commercial banks to be converted into Shari’ah-
compliant ones and for foreign entities to set up Islamic banks in cooperation with Indonesian 
partners. In July 2008, the Indonesian parliament approved the issuance of government sukuk 
worth $2 billion. Many see this as a strong indication of the administration’s increased attention 
to developing Shari’ah finance.8 In Singapore, the Monetary Authority of Singapore aims to play 
a complementary role by adding Shari’ah-compliant products to the broad range of financial 
services  offered  by  the  country’s  financial  institutions. To  this  end,  the  Monetary  Authority 
announced in May 2008 that it is developing a facility to make available Singapore dollar-
denominated, sovereign-rated sukuk to financial institutions in Singapore conducting Islamic 
finance. In addition, a 5% concessionary tax rate has been granted for income derived from 
Shari’ah-compliant fund management, lending, insurance, and re-insurance.9  
 
4.  The  efforts  in  the  region  to  develop  Islamic  finance  have  prepared  an  enabling 
environment for ADB further to spur the growth of Islamic finance. By enhancing regional 
financial integration and contributing to managing capital inflows into the region, these efforts 
should contribute to regional financial market stability. In this context, ADB’s Office of the 
General Counsel formed an internal working group on Islamic finance to better coordinate ADB 
activities  in  this  area  and  developed  a  short  background  paper  on  Islamic  finance  with 
recommendations to enhance ADB support. ADB’s Office of Regional Economic Integration 
includes  a  section  in  AsianBondsOnline  on  Islamic  finance,  which  provides  information 
regarding Islamic finance market infrastructure, rules and regulations, as well as updates on 
Islamic finance activities and data in the region. In September 2008, ADB’s Private Sector 
Operations Department signed with IDB a landmark cofinancing agreement that will allow the 
two banks to work together on projects in common member countries. ADB and IDB will provide 
up to $2 billion equivalent, respectively, over the next 3 years to finance projects in common 
member countries.10 
 
5.  Most  countries  have  separate  conventional  and  Islamic  banks,  but  others  allow 
conventional banks to set up Islamic windows. Despite the potential and improvements to date, 
the regulatory and supervision framework, markets, and instruments still suffer from significant 
gaps. In consequence, the Islamic finance industry has highlighted that one of the biggest 
challenges facing its integration into the global financial system is to harmonize standards as 
needed to sustain its continued rapid growth. TA for the Development of International Prudential 
Standards for Islamic Financial Services was a landmark project that resulted in IFSB’s adopting 
a new transparency and market discipline standard, new compilation guidelines for collecting 
Islamic finance statistics, identification and initial analysis of key issues and gaps in Islamic

finance  regulation  and  supervision,  and  recommendations  for  strengthening  the  legal  and 
regulatory framework for Islamic asset securitization as a basis for developing Islamic capital 
markets. This work also complemented that already ongoing to design prudential standards for 
Islamic finance in the areas of capital adequacy, supervisory review, and risk management. It 
also helped provide Basel II equivalent standards and guidelines for Islamic finance.  
 
6.  Accordingly, the key immediate challenges going forward are apparent. First, there is a 
clear need to implement the new standards and compilation guidelines11 at the country level, as 
well as to further develop and clarify the recommendations on a legal and regulatory framework 
for asset securitization prior to its adoption by IFSB as a guideline. Also needed is to effectively 
implement the strategies for developing Islamic money and government securities markets, as 
well as to review experiences as implementation progress. In regard to developing money and 
government securities markets, it should be noted that the IFSB has received assistance from 
the International Monetary Fund (IMF). A study from the IMF noted that there are important 
areas for further development, including to develop capital markets based on Islamic finance 
instruments. These would include markets for sovereign sukuk issues as part of public debt and 
financing arrangements at country level. The issue of developing sukuk markets has assumed 
particular importance because of the growing demand for infrastructure financing (for which 
Islamic finance is particularly suited) and the parallel growth in demand for sukuk in the Middle 
East and in Southeast Asia.   
 
7.   Based on the above, and to further support Islamic finance’s development to meet its 
potential, a number of activities are also required in the medium term. First, continued efforts 
are needed toward mutual recognition and harmonization of standards within the context of 
emerging global standards being developed by IFSB. Second, support is needed to help the 
policymakers and regulators to ensure that market infrastructure is fully developed. Third, active 
participation of private sector representatives is required for the industry’s development. Finally, 
further  policy  support  and  assessments  of  binding  constraints  are  needed  so  that  Islamic 
financing  can  better  fulfill  its  mandate  to  support  economic  development  of  the  relevant 
countries. It is expected that this will require two to three additional TA projects over a 5-year 
medium-term framework. This will be undertaken with a view toward deepening and widening 
partnerships with such key Islamic finance partners as IFSB, IDB, and others.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact of the proposed TA is greater harmonization and broader mutual recognition 
in Islamic financial markets, and in the Southeast Asian region, through the establishment of 
international  prudential  standards  for  Islamic  banks  and  financial  institutions,  an  effective 
regulatory and supervisory framework, and a robust legal and liquidity infrastructure needed for 
the sound development of Islamic finance. The outcome of the TA will be selected IFSB and 
ADB member countries taking actions to harmonize prudential standards, data collection, and 
commercial risk measurement. The TA has been coordinated with, and will complement, the 
work undertaken by ADB’s Office of Regional Economic Integration in Southeast Asia.  
 
                                                 
11 The standards currently issued by the IFSB include Capital Adequacy (2005), Risk Management (2005), Corporate 
Governance (2006), Transparency & Market Discipline through Disclosure (2007), and Supervisory Review Process (2007).

4 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  The TA will be conducted in consultation and coordination with IFSB staff and members, 
including IDB, IMF, World Bank, and the Bank for International Settlements. IFSB, through its 
technical committees and working groups, will continue to provide a forum for discussing key 
issues  in  developing  international  standards.  ADB  and  IDB  in  cooperation  with  IFSB  will 
coordinate closely with other multilateral and bilateral donors, including the IMF, World Bank, 
and Financial Sector Reform and Strengthening Initiative for strategically utilizing resources and 
sequencing assistance. Aspects of the TA will address issues in developing Islamic money and 
capital  markets.  Following  the  adoption  of  major  IFSB  standards,  guidelines,  and  strategy 
documents, the next step will focus in particular on facilitating their implementation. This TA 
aims  to  facilitate  implementation  of  the  standards,  guidelines,  and  market  development 
strategies. The key TA activities include the following: 
(i)  Help IFSB develop legal and liquidity infrastructure needed for Islamic finance’s 
sound development and effective supervision. As a part of efforts to develop liquidity 
infrastructure, specific aspects of the strategy for Islamic money and government 
securities markets will be worked out in detail, including guidance on qualitative and 
quantitative  benchmarks  for  regulatory  requirements  and  the  supervisory 
assessment  of  liquidity  risk  management.  To  strengthen  the  legal  infrastructure, 
certain key legal Shari`ah issues in Islamic asset securitization will be addressed.12 
(ii)  Support IFSB in working out strategies for Islamic capital market development in 
coordination  with  IFSB’s  ongoing  work  on  liquidity  infrastructure.  The  work  will 
include  measures  to  strengthen  sovereign  sukuk  issues  in  domestic  markets, 
integrate  sukuk  issuance  in  the  overall  public  debt  and  financing  management 
framework, and develop active and well-regulated secondary markets for sukuk. 
(iii)  Assist IFSB in preparing a diagnostic study in the area of interface between positive 
laws and the Shari’ah across all types of Shari’ah-compliant asset securitization 
contracts. This shall include a platform to engage legal jurists and Shari’ah scholars 
to find solutions for complex legal and Shari’ah issues through advanced sharing of 
jurisprudential thoughts and methodologies.  
(iv)  Help IFSB provide further education on the IFSB standards and guidelines through 
case studies and workshops to facilitate implementation of the standards. 
(v)  Assist IFSB in continuing the efforts to compile prudential and structural Islamic 
finance indicators based on the compilation guide already developed. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
10.  Total cost of the TA is estimated at $850,000 equivalent. ADB will finance $425,000 
equivalent on a grant basis from its TA funding program (Technical Assistance Special Fund—
other sources) and $425,000 equivalent will be financed on a grant basis by IFSB. The IFSB 
contributions will be administered by ADB. The funds will cover remuneration, travel, and per 
diem  for  international  consultants  and  resource  persons,  as  well  as  conference-related 
expenditures,  participants’  travel  costs,  other  training  expenditures,  and  miscellaneous 
expenses to gather views on the feasibility of the TA’s proposals, disseminate its findings, and 
facilitate agreement on new initiatives and actions. The detailed cost estimates and financing 
plan are in Appendix 2. No activity will be financed in any member country under this TA unless

and until a letter of no objection, if needed, in respect of such activity has been received from

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
11.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA, while the Implementing Agency will be 
IFSB. Public workshops will be held in IFSB countries to disseminate information and the TA’s 
findings on Islamic finance. The workshops will include all participating countries and agencies, 
as well as interested public and private sector parties. IFSB will maintain a public database on 
the industry with free international access to promote a better international understanding and 
assessment  of  Islamic  financial  markets.  Review  of  the  TA  will  be  provided  through  ADB 
missions, regular communications with IFSB, and standard reports (inception, midterm, and 
final). The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from March 2009 to February 2011.  
 
12.  ADB will recruit a firm to provide international consulting services. The TA will finance 
the services of 30 person-months of international consulting services to be implemented over a 
period of 24 months with activities expected to commence in March 2009. The international 
consultants will include a senior Islamic finance supervisory and regulatory expert who will also 
be  the  project  coordinator,  a  senior  financial  sector  and  statistical  expert,  senior  financial 
supervision and training expert, a senior legal expert, senior money and government securities 
market expert, and a senior Islamic capital market and tax expert. The consultants will be 
engaged  by  ADB  in  accordance  with  its  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  (2007,  as 
amended from time to time). Single-source selection of international consultants will be used, 
taking into consideration especially (i) the natural continuation of work in relation to the TA for 
the Development of International Prudential Standards for Islamic Financial Services: Development 
of International Prudential Standards for Islamic Financial Services carried out successfully by 
the consulting firm from July 2005 to March 2007, (ii) the consulting firm’s successful experience 
in managing and forging cross-country collaboration among national entities under the TA, and 
(iii) the highly specialized nature of many of the assignments. The consulting firm will be 
selected through biodata technical proposal. Disbursements under the TA will be made in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.13 The outline terms of 
reference for consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
13.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $425,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Islamic Financial Services Board, and (ii) ADB providing the 
balance not exceeding the equivalent of $425,000 on a grant basis for the Development of 
Prudential and Supervision Standards for Islamic Financial Markets, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

a  Displaced commercial risk (DCR) refers to risks that Islamic banking institutions absorb losses or forgo their share of 
profits to ensure that profit-sharing investment account holders (in conventional banking, simply put, they can be 
considered as depositors) enjoy the market return on similar investment. Application of DCR requires Islamic banking 
institutions to allocate adequate capital to cover credit and market risks exposures arising from the assets funded by 
the profit-sharing investment account, which would otherwise be absorbed by the investment account holders. This 
measurement of additional risk borne by the Islamic banking institutions arising from the application of DCR is 
represented by alpha (a), which quantifies the risk to be absorbed by the Islamic banking institutions for the purpose 
of the risk-weighted capital ratio calculation under the capital adequacy framework.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) will recruit a firm to provide international consulting 
services.  The  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  finance  the  services  of  30  person-months  of 
international consulting services to be implemented over a period of 24 months, with activities 
expected to commence in March 2009 and be completed by February 2011. The international 
consultants will include a senior Islamic finance supervisory and regulatory expert who will also 
be the project coordinator, a senior financial sector and statistical expert, a senior financial 
supervision  and  training  expert,  a  senior  legal  expert,  a  senior  money  and  government 
securities market expert, and a senior Islamic capital market and tax expert. 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
2.  The Islamic finance component will be conducted in consultation and coordination with 
the  Islamic  Financial  Services  Board  (IFSB).  ADB,  in  cooperation  with  IFSB  and  Islamic 
Development Bank, will also coordinate with other multilateral and bilateral agencies, including 
the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, to ensure strategic utilization of resources 
and sequencing of assistance. The consultants will be engaged to (i) help develop the legal and 
liquidity  infrastructure  needed  for  sound  development  and  effective  supervision  of  Islamic 
finance, (ii) develop strategies for Islamic capital market development in coordination with the 
ongoing work by the IFSB on liquidity infrastructure and Islamic asset securitization, (iii) provide 
further education on the IFSB standards and guidelines in order to facilitate implementation of 
the standards, and (iv) provide further guidance on specific elements of the existing standards 
to assist in developing regulatory requirements or support the supervisory review process. The 
tasks of the consultants will include, but not be limited to, the following. 
 
1.  Islamic  Finance  Regulatory  and  Supervisory  Expert  and  Project 
Coordinator (10 person-months) (team leader) 
 
3.  The team leader will be responsible for overall organization and management of the TA 
and timely delivery of outputs. The leader will be an experienced regulatory and supervisory 
expert with knowledge of the bank and nonbank sectors and of international best practices and 
standards (including IFSB standards). Also needed are fundamental knowledge of the principles 
of Islamic finance and the specific requirements for Shari’ah (Islamic law) compliance plus 
experience in Asia. The team leader should have experience in managing complex financial 
sector projects, including in Islamic finance. The team leader will undertake these tasks: 
(i)  Oversee implementation of TA deliverables, including to prepare an inception 
report with a work plan for each consultant and a time frame for deliverables and 
related workshops, plus the midterm, draft final, and final reports. Coordinate 
work of other experts. 
(ii)  As a basis for strengthening baseline supervision of Islamic finance, identify the 
focus areas and conceptual framework and issues for designing core principles 
of effective supervision and regulation of Islamic finance. Prepare a draft study, 
taking into account the special risk characteristics of Islamic finance and its 
cross-sectoral  features,  in  cooperation  and  consultation  with  IFSB  staff  and 
members. Participate in working meetings of officials and experts, as designated 
by IFSB. This study will feed into the work (under this TA, item [v] below) on 
facilitating IFSB standards implementation. 
(iii)  Prepare  draft  guidelines  on  measurement  and  management  of  displaced 
commercial  risk,  and  on  the  estimation  of  “alpha”  in  the  IFSB  supervisory 
discretion formula for capital adequacy, based on appropriate statistical studies.

designated by IFSB. 
(iv)  Identify the specific market development and supervisory and regulatory issues 
that arise in implementing the core principles and guidelines noted in items (ii) 
and (iii) above, and make recommendations for strengthening the infrastructure 
and/or issuance of additional international prudential standards. 
(v)  Coordinate the work of the senior legal expert, senior statistical expert, senior 
money market and government securities market expert, senior supervision and 
training expert, and senior Islamic capital market and tax expert, including to help 
review their contributions to ensure overall consistency of recommendations to IFSB.  
(vi)  Participate in workshops and forums in cooperation with IFSB for IFSB members, 
regulators, international organizations, and the private sector on implementing 
the IFSB standards and best practices for the industry. 
 
2.  International  Legal  Expert  on  Securities  Laws  and  Islamic  Finance  (4 
person-months) 
 
4.  The consultant will be an experienced legal expert with extensive knowledge of trust 
contract and securities laws. A fundamental knowledge of the principles of Islamic finance and 
the specific requirements for Shari’ah compliance plus experience in Asia are also needed. The 
expert will undertake these tasks in consultation with IFSB staff and members: 
(i)  Prepare key principles for developing an appropriate legal framework (including 
trust law and contract law) for Shari’ah-compliant asset securitization, based on a 
review of country experience, and participate in the legal seminar to be organized 
by IFSB. 
(ii)  In support of item (i), prepare a cross-country comparison and analysis of key 
impediments to an effective process for Shari’ah-compliant asset securitization, 
including the issues that arise in the interaction between conventional trust laws 
and contract laws and the Shari’ah rules and principles. The list of countries to be 
included in the international comparison shall be as agreed by IFSB and ADB. 
(iii)  Help  conduct  a  legal  seminar  that  would  discuss,  among  other  things,  the 
proposed key principles plus applications across jurisdictions and their impacts. 
(iv)  Help develop, in coordination with the international capital market expert and 
project coordinator, the core components of a strategy to promote Islamic capital 
markets. 
 
3.  Financial Sector and Statistical Expert (4 person-months) 
 
5.  The consultant will be an experienced senior financial sector and economics expert with 
experience in financial statistics and financial stability issues. A fundamental knowledge of 
issues  in  the  compilation  and  dissemination  of  financial  soundness  indicators  and  other 
statistical series on the financial sector is needed, as is background in applying these to compile 
Prudential and Structural Islamic Finance Indicators.1 The expert will undertake the following 
tasks in consultation with IFSB staff and members and the project coordinator: 
(i)  Drawing on the compilation guide prepared by the IFSB, help develop a program 
for collecting metadata and data on a pilot basis in selected IFSB members and

make  recommendations  for  strengthening  compilation  and  dissemination  of 
Prudential and Structural Islamic Finance Indicators. 
(ii)  Prepare an analysis of metadata and make recommendations to achieve cross-
country data comparability. 
(iii)  In cooperation with the project coordinator, analyze the reported cross-country 
data and any adjusted data to identify key characteristics and trends. 
(iv)  Provide recommendations for reporting formats and a management information 
system for a sustainable IFSB database to support public access as well as 
internal reporting.  
 
4.  Money Market and Government Securities Market Expert (4 person-months) 
 
6.  The  expert  will  have  a  background  in  monetary  operations  and  money  market 
development issues, as well as in government debt management and government finance 
issues. A basic knowledge of Islamic finance will be helpful to apply the best practices in 
conventional finance to developing Islamic money and government securities markets. The 
expert will undertake these tasks: 
(i)  Draw on the technical note prepared by the Islamic money market task force, 
further review country experiences, and develop action plans for implementing a 
money market development strategy in those countries that will volunteer for 
implementation on a pilot basis. 
(ii)  Based on the country experiences, identify areas requiring additional guidance, 
including  such  areas  as  integrating  the  issue  program  for  Islamic  finance 
instruments  with  the  domestic  public  debt  and  financing  management 
arrangements, design of monetary operations incorporating both conventional 
and Islamic financial institutions, design of Islamic repos and related issues 
important to developing these markets. 
(iii)  In cooperation with the project coordinator and financial supervision expert, help 
develop  broad  principles  and  benchmarks  on  liquidity  risk  management  in 
Islamic finance. 
(iv)  Participate in working meetings of officials and experts that may be organized to 
exchange experiences and discuss guidelines in the area of Islamic money and 
government securities market development. 
 
5.  Islamic Finance Supervision and Training Expert (4 person-months) 
 
7.  The  expert  will  have  extensive  senior  level  experience  as  a  banking  supervisor,  a 
background in supervising Islamic financial institutions, and strong familiarity with the IFSB 
standards. The expert will undertake these tasks: 
(i)  Develop  and  review  workshop  materials  (e.g.,  case  studies,  illustrative 
presentations  based  on  the  IFSB  standards)  in  consultation  with  the  IFSB 
Standards Implementation Unit and the project coordinator. 
(ii)  Conduct workshops to guide and train IFSB staff in the standards. 
(iii)  Review and address issues raised during workshops and propose solutions. 
(iv)  Participate in the workshops and forums and give presentations on selected 
topics as needed to ensure the effectiveness of the program.

12  Appendix 3 
6.  Islamic Capital Market and Tax Expert (4 person-months) 
 
8.   The  expert  will  have  both  extensive  experience  in  conventional  capital  market 
development issues and a background in designing and developing Islamic capital market 
instruments, including tax incentive schemes. The expert will undertake these tasks: 
(i)  Review  country  experiences  and  international  developments  in  structuring, 
issuing, and marketing sukuk (Islamic securities), along with the factors affecting 
their costs and liquidity. 
(ii)  Work with the legal expert and project coordinator in assessing the legal and 
other impediments to Islamic capital market development, plus identify the core 
legal, institutional, and operational issues to be addressed in developing the 
Islamic capital markets. 
(iii)  Design tax incentives to help develop Islamic capital market development. 
(iv)  Based  on  items  (i)  and  (ii),  help  develop  a  strategic  framework  for  the 
development of Islamic capital markets. 
(v)  Help organize and participate in conferences or working meetings that might be 
organized to discuss Islamic capital market development issues.
